Their ire was ignited by the King's perceived tyranny in stripping them of their English citizenship rights, disregarding their colonial governments, and dispatching mercenary troops to subjugate them under unjust laws. The colonists held the King in low esteem, deeming him unworthy of ruling over a free people. In their eyes, he had become an impediment to their liberty and self-determination, prompting them to pen the Declaration of Independence and embark on the path of revolution.

Eventually, Braddock relented and adopted Washington\'s suggestion to send an advance force of 1,200 men forward without wagons, leaving Washington behind. However, this advance force was harassed by marauding Indians who took scalps, terrifying the British regulars. Washington regained enough strength to rejoin Braddock on July 8th along the Monongahela River, about 12 miles upstream of The Forks of the Ohio. On July 9th, the English force, spread out over a mile-long track, attempted to ford the Monongahela twice while sending Major Gage forward with an advance force to protect the fords from ambush. Around 2:30 PM, Gage\'s troops were ambushed, causing the terrified redcoats to break ranks and retreat in confusion. Braddock and other officers tried to calm the men but failed. The British officers, except for Washington, were either wounded or killed. Colonial troops attempted to fight the French on their own terms in the woods but were mistakenly fired upon by their British allies. Despite the defeat being one of the worst in British colonial history, Washington emerged as a "bullet proof hero of the Monongahela."']

My efforts, in conjunction with those of the British and American forces, contributed to the capture of Fort Duquesne and ultimately led to the British victory in the war.

ground_truths: ['The capture and renaming of Fort Duquesne to Fort Pitt marked a significant turning point in the French and Indian War by ending French claims to the Ohio Valley and establishing British control over the region. In late November 1758, the French, believing the British would not strike until spring, evacuated Fort Duquesne after destroying their cannon. Washington and his vanguard marched in on November 25, 1758, and raised the British flag on the ruins, renaming it Fort Pitt. This event concluded five years of conflict to secure the Forks of the Ohio, with peace established between the British and local Indian tribes. George Washington played a key role by leading his troops to occupy the fort and later viewing the transformation of the French fort into Fort Pitt on Christmas morning 1758. His leadership during this campaign and subsequent decision to resign and return to Mount Vernon in early 1759 marked the end of his military service in the war and the beginning of his life as a landowner and public figure.']
